subSubSection.paragraph:
The male of
K. pentacantha
resembles that of
K. quadrata
sp. nov. by the shape of the tegulum and embolus ( Fig. 11C, E ); however, it can be distinguished by its stout and conical RTA ( Figs 11D, F , 19A ) and larger body size, since they are the largest males of genus, being the sexual size dimorphism in this species less pronounced. Females can be recognized by the external genitalia bearing a noticeable median septum and a pair of long longitudinal depressions leading to the copulatory openings ( Figs 10C, E , 22A ). The most common body color pattern for both males and females usually present a diagnostic median white spot on the dorsum of the opisthosoma ( Figs 10A , 11A).

subSubSection.paragraph: 7.74. Total body length 9.81; carapace 4.14 length, 3.83 width; opisthosoma length 4.87; clypeus 0.28 height; sternum 1.41 length, 1.12 width; endites 0.74 length, 0.38 width; labium 0.41 length, 0.51 width.
OPISTHOSOMA. As in female, except by the shorter median posterior opisthosomal projection and the lack of agglomerated orange tubercles.
